translation: A long projecting beam or girder fixed at only one end, used in bridge construction.
The face of a building, especially the principal front that looks onto a street or open space.
The design and placement of windows in a building.
The triangular upper part of the front of a building in classical style, typically surmounting a portico of columns.
The outside corner of a wall or building, often reinforced and made more prominent than the rest of the wall.
A style of architecture which uses local materials and traditions to construct buildings.
A rectangular column that projects only slightly from a wall and resembles a classical column.
The lowest part of an entablature in classical architecture, resting directly on top of the columns.
An upper portion of a wall containing windows for supplying natural light to a building.
The top section of an entablature, often projecting from the wall to throw rainwater clear of the building.
A wall that supports the weight of the house above it, in addition to its own weight.
A vertical or horizontal element that forms a division between units of a window or screen.
A low protective wall or barrier at the edge of a balcony, roof, or bridge.
A retaining wall or facing of masonry or other material, supporting or protecting a rampart, embankment, or the like.
A framework, typically consisting of rafters, posts, and struts, supporting a roof, bridge, or other structure.
A process for researching and deciding on the goals and requirements of a construction project before starting the design phase.
Short pillars or columns in a series that support a rail, often used on staircases or balconies.
A software program used in architectural design to create 3D models of buildings.
Governmental regulations that control the use of land within a community.
A horizontal structure supported by columns, usually consists of an architrave, a frieze, and a cornice.
The triangular upper part of a wall that encloses the end of a pitched roof.
A type of roof where all sides slope downwards to the walls, usually with a gentle slope.
A horizontal support of timber, stone, concrete, or steel across the top of a door or window.
An architectural structure built against or projecting from a wall which serves to support or reinforce the wall.
A window that projects vertically from a sloping roof.
The part of a roof that meets or overhangs the walls of a building.
A beam with an I or H-shaped cross-section, used in construction for its ability to handle a lot of weight.
Horizontal structural elements that are used to support a ceiling or floor.
The face or front of a building, often the most decorative part.
An arched form used to provide a space with a ceiling or roof, often seen in churches or cathedrals.
A type of roof where all sides slope downwards to the walls, usually with a fairly gentle slope.
A low storey between two others in a building, typically between the ground and first floors.
A horizontal beam along the length of a roof, resting on principals and used to support common rafters or boards.
The space between two arches or between an arch and a rectangular enclosure.
A thin decorative covering of fine wood applied to a coarser wood or other material.
An area of wooden paneling on the lower part of the walls of a room.
A layer of material applied to the exterior of a building to protect it from the weather and provide a decorative finish.
A railing supported by balusters, especially one forming an ornamental parapet to a balcony, bridge, or terrace.
The external angle or corner of a building. In architecture, they are often decorative and add character to a building.
The underside of any construction element, such as an arch, balcony, or overhanging eaves.
Building Information Modeling, a digital representation of physical and functional characteristics of a building.
Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, a globally recognized symbol of sustainability achievement and leadership.
The process of updating old structures with new technologies or features to improve functionality or energy efficiency.
A carved stone creature with a spout designed to convey water from a roof and away from the side of a building.
A wedge-shaped or tapered stone used to construct an arch.
A horizontal representation of a building, as if it was cut at eye level and seen from above.
A vertical representation of a building or its parts, as if it was seen from a straight-on view.
The part of a roof that overhangs the walls of a building.
A spiral or scroll-like ornament found in the capital of a column.
A small tower on top of a larger tower or at the corner of a building or wall, typically of a castle.
A four-sided gambrel-style hip roof characterized by two slopes on each of its sides with the lower slope being steeper.
A rectangular stepped tower, sometimes surmounted by a temple, which was commonly built in ancient Mesopotamia.
Masonry cut in large blocks separated from each other by deep joints, used to ornate the exterior walls of a building.
A wall that supports additional weight from the structure above it, not just its own weight.
The use of land within a built-up area for further construction, especially as part of a community redevelopment.
The physical barrier between the interior and the exterior of a building, including the walls, roof, and foundation.
The semi-circular or triangular decorative wall surface over an entrance, bounded by a lintel and arch.
A small entryway or lobby within a building.
A specific form of buttress, or support, for a wall, that extends from the wall to a pier some distance away.
An exit or a means of exiting - typically designed for emergencies.
A structure consisting of a roof supported by columns at regular intervals, typically attached as a porch to a building.
The addition of new technology or features to older systems.
A wall that carries the weight from the structure above it, as well as its own weight.
A hollow, rounded roof structure that is shaped like half of a sphere and is often used to cover large spaces.
A small, thin column, often used for decoration or to support an arcade.
A style of ancient Greek or Roman architecture, the simplest of the classical orders, characterized by heavy fluted columns with plain, saucer-shaped tops and no base.
A pointed arch, typically found in Gothic style architecture.
In ancient Greece and Rome, an open-air venue used for horse and chariot racing and other public events.
One of the three orders of classical Greek architecture, characterized by two opposed volutes in the capital.
The wedge-shaped stone at the top of an arch that locks the other stones in place.
A frame with horizontal slats angled to admit light and air, but to keep out rain, direct sunshine, and noise.
The visible part of the side of a window or door opening that is between the outer surface of a wall and the window or door frame.
A broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration, especially on a wall near the ceiling.
The side part of a doorway or window.
A detailed outline of a client's design objectives, including space and facility requirements.
These are supporting columns that lift a building off the ground, providing space underneath for parking or green areas.
A structure in a garden that is made from a framework of horizontal trelliswork supported on columns.
An arrangement of parallel, angled slats or blades in a door, window, or wall to allow air and light to pass through.
Ornamental stonework in the upper part of a Gothic window.
A series of arches supported by columns, piers, or pillars, either freestanding or attached to a wall to form a gallery.
A vertical structural element, strong in compression, that supports weight above it.
The heavy base or platform upon which a column, pedestal, statue, or structure rests.
A non-structural outer covering of a building that keeps the weather out and the occupants in.
The area of ground covered by a structure, often used to assess the impact of a building on its surrounding environment.
A type of plaster used as a coating for walls and ceilings, and for decoration.
A window that protrudes from a sloping roof, allowing more natural light into the upper floor or attic.
A hard, fired clay, brownish-red in color when unglazed, used in architectural construction and decoration.
A type of facade without any columns or pilasters.
The total amount of light falling on a surface, used as a measure of how well-lit a space is.
A sturdy wall built to hold back earth or water from a structure or area.
A continuous horizontal band, usually molded, which travels across the façade of a building.
A ground-level supporting column. In modern architecture, it's often used to lift a building off the ground.
The resistance of a material to breaking under tension.
A style of architecture prevalent in Western Europe from the 12th to the 16th centuries, characterized by pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses.
The covering piece on top of a wall which is exposed to the weather, usually made of stone or concrete.
A large open space located within a building, often featuring a glass roof for natural light.
Refers to a style of architecture that uses local materials and traditions to reflect the cultural, environmental, and historical context of the area.
A German design movement from the 20th century that combines crafts and the fine arts, known for its simplicity and functionality.
The lower part of a wall, below the dado rail and above the skirting board.
A type of construction technique using individual units (like bricks or stones) laid in and bound together by mortar.
Steel bar or mesh of steel wires used as a tension device in reinforced concrete and masonry structures.
A type of failure of a structural element subjected to high localized forces, looking as if the material has been 'punched' out.
A deposit of salts, usually white, formed on the surface of materials like concrete or brick when water evaporates from the material.
A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
A number system only using two digits, 0 and 1, used by almost all modern computers and computer-based devices.
A hardware or software component that stores data so future requests for that data can be served faster.
A specific way to store and organize data in a computer's memory for efficient access and modification.
The process of converting information into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.
A type of artificial intelligence where computer systems can learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed.
The primary software that manages all the hardware and software on a computer.
The human-readable instructions that a programmer writes, typically in a high-level programming language.
A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
A type of computer memory that temporarily stores frequently used data for quick access.
A programming model organized around objects, which are data structures that contain data and procedures.
A programming concept where a function calls itself to solve a smaller part of the problem.
The most basic unit of information in computing and digital communications.
A program that translates high-level language into machine language that computers can understand.
A sequence of instructions that can be executed independently, yet shares resources with other threads of the same process.
A process used to organize a database into tables and columns to minimize redundancy and dependency.
A unique string of numbers and/or letters that identifies a device on a network.
Any software intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.
The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured in a particular programming language.
A mathematical notation that describes the limiting behavior of a function when the argument tends towards a particular value or infinity, often used in complexity analysis.
A system whose components are located on different networked computers, which communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to each other.
A technique where a single set of code can be used by several processors at different stages of execution.
A structured set of data stored in a computer, often for use in applications.
A device that forwards data packets between computer networks.
A computer that provides data or services to other computers over a network.
A set of rules and protocols for building and interacting with software applications.

The delivery of computing services—including servers, storage, databases, networking, software, analytics, and intelligence—over the Internet ('the cloud') to offer faster innovation, flexible resources, and economies of scale.
The practice of defending computers, servers, mobile devices, electronic systems, networks, and data from digital attacks.
A type of computation that makes direct use of quantum-mechanical phenomena, such as superposition and entanglement, to perform operations on data.
A system of recording information in a way that makes it difficult or impossible to change, hack, or cheat the system.
Extremely large data sets that can be analyzed to reveal patterns, trends, and associations.
The process of discovering patterns in large data sets using statistics and machine learning.
A series of algorithms that attempts to identify underlying relationships in a set of data through a process modeled on the human brain.
The core component of an operating system that manages operations of the computer and the hardware.
Software for which the source code is freely available to the public for use and modification from its original design.
Graphical User Interface, a system of interactive visual components for computer software.
A system of representing text or computer processor instructions by the use of the binary number system's two-binary digits 0 and 1.
An Application Programming Interface (API) is a set of rules and protocols for building software and applications.
A programming language used to manage and manipulate databases.
The address of a web page on the internet.
A unit of digital information storage, equivalent to approximately a billion bytes.
The physical parts of a computer system, such as the monitor, keyboard, and hard drive.
A programming language mostly used for interactive effects and web development.
A reference in a digital document that users can follow to access other content.
The principal communications protocol for relaying packets across network boundaries in the internet.
The main software that runs a computer, like Windows or MacOS.
A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
A method for finding a specific item in a sorted list by repeatedly dividing the list in half.
Specific ways of storing and organizing data in a computer so that it can be used efficiently.
A process that converts input data of any size into a fixed-size value, often used for quick data retrieval.
A principle in object-oriented programming that restricts direct access to some components of an object, to prevent accidental modification.
The practice and study of secure communication techniques in the presence of adversaries.
Short for Virtual Private Network, it extends a private network across a public network, allowing users to send and receive data as if their devices were directly connected to the private network.
A visual guide that represents the skeletal framework of a website or app, used in planning a site's structure and functionality.
A small segment of a larger network message. Data is divided into packets before it is sent over the internet.
A technique designed for solving a problem more quickly when classic methods are too slow, or for finding an approximate solution when classic methods fail to find any exact solution.
The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction for its transfer.
Data that provides information about other data. Like a book's summary, but for data.
A structure where each item has up to two successors, often visualized as a branching tree.
A phenomenon in which storage space is used inefficiently, reducing capacity or performance and often both.
A principle in object-oriented programming where a new class is formed using properties and methods of an existing class.
A concept in programming where objects of a superclass can be treated as objects of its subclass and vice versa.
Programs and operating information used by a computer.
A request for data or information from a database.
A set of rules that governs the connection of computer systems to the Internet.
A programming model where programs are organized around data, or objects, rather than functions and logic.
The practice of linking computers and other devices together to share resources and data.
A subset of algebra used for creating true/false statements.
A programming paradigm where programs are constructed by applying and composing functions.
A distributed version control system that tracks changes to source code during software development.
A region of a computer's memory space that is used for dynamic memory allocation.
A distributed architecture that partitions tasks or workloads between peers, allowing data to be shared directly between systems on the network.
A programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code to manipulate the data.
The network of physical devices connected to the internet, collecting and sharing data.
A set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data electronically between devices.
The means by which the user and a computer system interact, in particular the use of input devices and software.
Software for which the original source code is made freely available and may be redistributed and modified.
A function that calls itself during its execution, often used to solve complex problems by breaking them down into simpler steps.
An error in the sequence of characters or tokens that is intended to be written in a particular programming language.
A computer system that processes requests via HTTP, the basic network protocol used to distribute information on the World Wide Web.
An error, flaw, or fault in a computer program that causes it to produce incorrect or unexpected results.
A set of rules governing the format of data sent over the Internet or other network.
The process of finding and resolving defects or problems within a computer program that prevent correct operation of computer software or a system.
The part of web development that deals with what users see on their screens (like layout, design and interaction).
The server-side of development which focuses on how the site works and includes managing the database.
The process of creating a virtual version of something like computer hardware systems, storage devices, and network resources.
The process of converting data into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
A set of rules for how data is sent and received over the internet.
A unit of digital information that consists of 8 bits, often used to encode a single character of text.
A type of data that can only be True or False.
A programming function that repeats a sequence of instructions until a specific condition is met.
A system where multiple computers work together to solve a computational problem.
Random Access Memory, a type of computer memory that can be accessed randomly, used by the system to store data that it is currently working with.
A piece of code that performs a specific task and can be used multiple times.
A branch of computer science that aims to make computers behave like humans, or make decisions and learn from past experiences.
A comparison-based sorting method performed on data structures called heaps, and it's used to create a sorted list from unsorted data.
A situation in computing where two or more processes cannot proceed because each is waiting for the other to release resources.
A mathematical study of networks to model relationships between pairs of objects.
The process of translating code written in a high-level programming language into machine language that a computer can execute.
The period when a program is running. It starts when a program is opened (or loaded into memory) and ends with the program is quit or closed.
A problem-solving approach used for speed in finding a satisfactory solution, where an optimal solution is not feasible.
Software that creates and manages virtual machines on a server.
The network of physical devices, vehicles, and other items embedded with electronics, software, sensors, and connectivity which enables these things to connect and exchange data.
The part of a software application that the user interacts with directly.
The process of reducing the amount of data needed for the storage or transmission of a given piece of information.
A technology that allows electronic devices to connect to a wireless LAN (WLAN) network, mainly using the 2.4 gigahertz UHF and 5 gigahertz SHF ISM radio bands.
An application protocol for distributed, collaborative, hypermedia information systems, the foundation of any data exchange on the Web.
A high-level programming language used to develop software applications in a wide range of computing platforms.
A method in computing where multiple tasks are executed simultaneously to increase speed and efficiency.
Software that's embedded into a hardware device to control its functions.
A learning process where behavior is altered over time in response to certain stimuli.
A systematic error in thinking that affects the decisions and judgments that people make.
A therapy method that aims to uncover repressed thoughts, emotions, and memories in order to alleviate mental tension.
A learning process where behavior is shaped by reinforcement or punishment.
Strategies used by the unconscious mind to protect oneself from anxiety-inducing thoughts or feelings.
The brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections throughout life.
The process of realizing and fulfilling one's potential and capabilities.
A part of the unconscious mind shared among beings of the same species, containing inherited ancestral experiences.
The tendency to interpret new evidence as confirmation of one's existing beliefs or theories.
Behaviour that is driven by internal rewards, such as satisfaction or a sense of achievement.
The mental discomfort or stress experienced when holding two or more conflicting beliefs, values, or behaviors.
A defense mechanism where unpleasant or traumatic memories are pushed into the unconscious mind.
A defense mechanism where an individual attributes their own unacceptable feelings or thoughts to someone else.
When observations may be skewed by the observer's expectations or personal beliefs.
A cognitive bias where the perception of a person in one area influences one's overall perception of that individual.
The idea that a person's behavior both influences and is influenced by personal factors and the environment.
A model in psychology that ranks the basic human needs in a pyramid structure, from physiological needs to self-actualization.
The process of releasing strong or repressed emotions, often providing a sense of relief.
Brain chemical routes where dopamine travels, influencing mood, reward, and movement.
A belief that you control your own life and are responsible for your own actions.
The theory suggesting that an imbalance of the neurotransmitter dopamine may cause schizophrenia.
A child's understanding that objects continue to exist even when they cannot be seen, heard, or otherwise sensed.
When a person experiences a perceived improvement in condition due to their belief in the treatment, rather than the treatment itself.
An individual's belief in their capacity to execute behaviors necessary to produce specific performance attainments.
A social psychology theory that explains how people interpret events and how this relates to their thinking and behavior.
A mental shortcut that relies on immediate examples that come to a given person's mind when evaluating a specific topic, concept, method or decision.
A type of neurotransmitter, which is a substance in the brain that transmits signals between nerve cells. It's linked to feelings of pleasure.
A portion of long-term memory that processes ideas and concepts not drawn from personal experience.
A cognitive framework or concept that helps organize and interpret information.
A learning process where two stimuli are repeatedly paired and over time, the response to one stimulus is elicited by the other alone.
A situation where a therapist transfers emotions to a client—often a reflection of feelings experienced in past relationships.
A region of the brain responsible for things like hunger, mood, body temperature, and sleep.
The process of focusing on a particular object in the environment for a certain period of time, while ignoring irrelevant information.
The process of learning by watching others, retaining the information, and then later replicating the behaviors that were observed.
The memory of autobiographical events (times, places, associated emotions, and other contextual knowledge) that can be explicitly stated.
A psychotherapeutic process of learning to identify and dispute irrational or maladaptive thoughts.
The phenomenon in which the greater the number of people present, the less likely people are to help a person in distress.
An approach in psychology that emphasizes the study of observable behavior, not on mental processes.
Chemicals in the brain that transmit signals between nerve cells.
A type of psychological treatment that helps patients understand the thoughts and feelings that influence behaviors.
The study of mental disorders, including their symptoms, causes, and treatments.
Freud's theory that a child's personality develops through a series of childhood stages focused on pleasure areas.
A learned reaction to a conditioned stimulus.
A condition where a person's identity is fragmented into two or more distinct personality states.
The tendency to overestimate the effect of personality and underestimate the effect of the situation in explaining social behavior.
The tendency to believe, after an event has occurred, that one would have foreseen or predicted the outcome.
The process by which new neurons are generated in the hippocampus, a brain region involved in learning and memory.
The process of perceiving certain information and ignoring other information based on one's beliefs, attitudes, or decisions.
Motivation that comes from outside the individual, such as rewards, praise, or avoidance of punishment.
The idea that self-control or willpower is a limited resource that can be used up.
The growth and development of a person's social interactions and understanding of themselves and others.
A psychological theory that emphasizes the importance of 'attachment' in personal development, specifically between a child and their caregiver.
A theory suggesting that the way people relate to others and situations in their adult lives is shaped by family experiences during infancy.
A motivational theory in psychology comprising a five-tier model of human needs, often depicted as hierarchical levels within a pyramid.
An error in speech, memory or physical action that occurs due to the interference of unconscious thoughts or feelings.
A therapy method that encourages patients to engage in valued life activities even when they are feeling depressed.
Prejudices or stereotypes that influence our decisions and actions without us realizing it.
Recollections that are not part of our consciousness, like skills and habits.
A return to earlier stages of development and abandoned forms of gratification.
The part of the mind that is inaccessible to the conscious mind but influences behaviors and emotions.
The extent to which a test measures what it claims to measure.
A theory suggesting behavior and feelings are largely driven by unconscious thoughts.
A treatment method focused on changing negative thought patterns to improve mood and behavior.
An approach to psychology that emphasizes empathy and stresses the good in human behavior.
A decrease in sensitivity to a constant level of stimulation.
The phenomenon of a person exerting less effort to achieve a goal when they work in a group than when they work alone.
A psychological framework that attempts to identify patterns of behavior (traits) that make people unique.
Unconscious attitudes or stereotypes that affect our understanding, actions, and decisions.
A debate concerning whether genetics (nature) or environment and upbringing (nurture) have a greater effect on personality development.
Freud's theory of three parts of the psyche: the instinctual, the rational, and the moral.
The habit of attributing our successes to our own abilities and efforts while blaming outside factors for our failures.
A treatment approach, based on the principles of operant conditioning, that replaces undesirable behaviors with more desirable ones through positive or negative reinforcement.
A statistical process for estimating the relationships among variables.
A therapeutic approach focusing on unconscious processes and their influence on behavior.
Increasing the likelihood of a behavior by giving a reward when the behavior occurs.
A psychoanalytic technique where patients express thoughts exactly as they come to mind without conscious editing.
A method in psychology that focuses on the unique characteristics and life experiences of the individual.
A mental shortcut that allows people to solve problems and make judgments quickly and efficiently.
Brain cells that fire both when an individual acts and when the individual observes the same action performed by another.
The tendency to falsely project current preferences onto a future event.
Changes in behavior that occur when people know they're being observed.
Predicting how one will feel in the future after certain events or decisions.
Tools used to make inferences and predictions about a population based on a sample of data.
A theory suggesting that childhood experiences and unconscious desires influence behavior.
A deep-seated feeling of inadequacy and insecurity, often leading to overcompensation in other areas.
The process of adapting to stimuli that are constant and unchanging, resulting in reduced responses.
An unseen but measurable concept used to explain behavior, such as intelligence.
The idea that expressing aggressive or negative emotions can provide a sense of relief.
The ability to solve new problems, use logic in new situations, and identify patterns.
A person's belief about the extent to which they can control events affecting them.
The interplay between personal factors, environment, and behavior in understanding human behavior.
An emotional process where a person unconsciously projects a part of their personality onto another person.
Anxiety about big questions of life, death, freedom, and existence.
A condition where a person suffers from a sense of powerlessness, arising from persistent failure to succeed.
A research study that involves repeated observations of the same variables over long periods of time.
A mental disorder where people have unwanted and repeated thoughts, feelings, ideas, and behaviors.
A learning process where a neutral stimulus becomes associated with a significant stimulus, leading to a similar response.
A psychoanalytic therapy method where social transactions are analyzed to determine the ego state of the patient.
The body's stress response system, involving interaction between the brain and adrenal glands.
A mental disorder characterized by extreme mood swings from high (mania) to low (depression).
A defensive process where unacceptable thoughts and impulses are countered or concealed by exaggerated opposite feelings.
The tendency of individuals to feel less responsible for action or inaction when others are present.
Automatic psychological strategies used to protect the mind from anxiety-inducing thoughts or feelings.
A therapeutic approach designed to change a particular undesirable negative behavior by using a system of rewards and consequences.
A disconnection between a person's thoughts, memories, feelings, actions, or sense of who he or she is.
The act of matching attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors to group norms.
An expectation that people will respond favorably to each other by returning benefits for benefits, and responding with either indifference or hostility to harms.
An unconscious psychological strategy that the mind uses to protect itself from distressing thoughts, feelings or impulses.
A type of psychotherapeutic treatment that helps individuals understand the thoughts and feelings that influence behaviors.
Unconscious psychological strategies used by individuals to cope with reality and maintain self-image.
A period of exploration where an individual seeks to understand their identity, often occurring during adolescence.
A natural, internal process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours.
A situation in which an individual is given two different and incompatible demands, and cannot avoid being in conflict with one or the other.
A substance that binds to a specific receptor and triggers a response in the cell, often mimicking the action of a naturally occurring substance.
A phenomenon where previously learned information hinders the ability to remember new information.
A phenomenon where new information makes it harder to recall old information.
A section of the brain important for learning and memory.
Chemicals in the brain that transmit signals from a neuron to a target cell across a synapse.
The expression of mental phenomena as physical (somatic) symptoms.
Remembering to perform a planned action or intention at the appropriate time in the future.
Something that triggers a natural, reflexive response without any learning.
The gap between what a learner can do without help and what they can't do, even with assistance.
Unconscious strategies that the mind uses to protect itself from distress.
A theory suggesting that our emotional response to a situation is based on our interpretation of that situation.
The tendency for people to perform differently when in the presence of others than when alone.
A prediction that directly or indirectly causes itself to become true due to positive feedback between belief and behavior.
The influence of other people on our behavior to be accepted and liked by them.
Study of changes in organisms due to modification of gene expression, not alteration of the genetic code itself.
A neurological disorder characterized by the inability to recognize faces.
The process of investing mental or emotional energy into a person, object, or idea.
A model that suggests biological, psychological, and social factors all play a significant role in human functioning.
The observed tendency of people to return to a relatively stable level of happiness despite major positive or negative events in their lives.
In learning theory, a schedule of reinforcement where a response is sometimes rewarded, leading to more resistant and persistent behavior.
A model of intelligence that divides it into three parts: analytical (problem-solving), creative (innovation), and practical (common sense).
Part of the brain involved in decision-making, personality expression, and moderating social behavior.
Physical symptoms caused by mental or emotional distress.
A type of psychotherapy that aims to change harmful behaviors through a system of rewards and reinforcements.
The decreased ability to learn new information due to prior exposure to the same information.
A psychological theory that argues behavior is driven by unconscious thoughts, feelings, and memories.
The part of short-term memory involved in the temporary storage and manipulation of information.
The removal of an adverse stimulus to increase the behavior that leads to it.
The psychological phenomenon by which people tend to develop a preference for things merely because they are familiar with them.
A hormone that plays a key role in social bonding, sexual reproduction, childbirth, and the period after childbirth.
A personality trait characterized by outgoing, energetic behavior and a preference for social interaction.
A physical illness or other condition caused or aggravated by a mental factor such as internal conflict or stress.
A curved triangle of vaulting formed by the intersection of a dome with its supporting arches.
An approach to architecture that seeks to minimize environmental impact through energy efficiency and resource conservation.
A structural element that supports and transfers weight from the building to the foundation.
Materials in a building that store and release heat, helping to regulate indoor temperatures.
Regulations that dictate how land can be used and what types of buildings can be constructed in certain areas.
A detailed architectural plan or drawing that outlines the design and specifications of a building.
A roof covered with vegetation that helps improve insulation and reduce stormwater runoff.
A structural element that supports weight from above, such as walls or beams.
Designing buildings in a way that minimizes environmental impact and promotes resource efficiency.
An architectural feature that provides shade to reduce heat gain from the sun.
A design approach that uses standardized units or sections to create a larger structure.
An ancient Chinese practice that arranges spaces to promote harmony and energy flow.
A design principle where elements are unevenly balanced, creating visual interest and dynamism.
A architectural feature designed to block sunlight while allowing natural light to enter a building.
An architectural approach that seeks to minimize environmental impact through energy efficiency and resource conservation.
A design process that uses algorithms and parameters to define and manipulate shapes and forms.
The study and design of cities, focusing on the arrangement and organization of urban spaces.
The flow of movement within a building, including pathways and openings that facilitate access between spaces.
An approach that considers the surrounding environment and cultural factors when designing a building.
The evaluation of a location to determine its suitability for construction.
A building design that uses tension to support its form, often with a fabric or membrane.
The outer shell of a building, including walls, roofs, and windows, that protects against environmental elements.
Creating a preliminary model of a building or structure to test concepts and design before full-scale construction.
The process of repurposing old buildings for new uses while retaining their historic features.
A deck that extends out from a building without support underneath, creating an overhang.
The physical layout and structure of a city, including its buildings, streets, and public spaces.
A measure of thermal resistance used to determine insulation effectiveness in buildings.
A set of regulations governing the design and construction of buildings to ensure safety and health.
The weight and forces that a structure must support, including its own weight and any additional loads.
A scaled diagram that shows the layout of a building from a top-down perspective.
An architectural layout that minimizes walls to create large, open spaces within a building.
A passive solar building design that uses a wall to collect and store heat from the sun.
